history_of_present_illness: During the second week of a 3.5-week trip to the Peruvian Amazon, the patient developed an acute febrile illness with chills, malaise, frontal headache, generalized myalgia, and a transient, non-pruritic maculopapular rash. The rash started on forearms, spread to trunk, neck, and face, then faded after 3 days. He also experienced slowly progressive debilitating polyarthralgias affecting peripheral joints with transient joint swelling, and painful cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy which lasted about 1 week. He was clinically diagnosed with dengue fever at a local hospital and treated with paracetamol. Fever and other symptoms subsided within 1 week, but polyarthralgias persisted, showing a symmetrical pattern mainly affecting small joints of hands and feet, wrists, ankles, and knees. Upon returning to Switzerland, he consulted his general practitioner for persisting polyarthralgias and joint stiffness (morning and after immobility). After two more months of un улучishing joint pains, he was referred to a rheumatologist and a tropical medicine clinic.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Spent 3.5 weeks travelling in the rainforests of the Amazon Basin in northern Peru. Returned from the Peruvian Amazon.
physical_exam: Physical examination was completely unremarkable. Affected joints did not reveal any clinical signs of inflammation (no swelling, no redness, no effusion).
labs_and_diagnostics: Serological testing for dengue virus, chikungunya virus, parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus, Borrelia burgdorferi, Chlamydia trachomatis, Salmonella Typhi, and S. Paratyphi was performed, but none revealed a cause for symptoms. Full blood count was normal. C-reactive protein was mildly elevated at 9 mg/L (<5). Liver function tests were normal.
differential_diagnosis: Initial clinical diagnosis was dengue fever. Later differential diagnoses considered were Reactive arthritis (Reiter’s syndrome) and Viral arthritis (including parvovirus B19, hepatitis B and C, HIV, rubella, and alphaviruses such as Chikungunya, Sindbis, Ross River, Barmah Forest, O’Nyong Nyong, Mayaro).
management_and_clinical_course: Received symptomatic treatment with paracetamol at a local hospital in Peru. Fever and other symptoms (except polyarthralgias) subsided within 1 week. Polyarthralgias did not improve for several weeks/months, leading to referrals to a rheumatologist and a tropical medicine clinic.
final_diagnosis: Mayaro virus (MAYV) infection was strongly suspected.
